latestVersion.availabilityStatus: Codebook is freely available; data is not public. Permission  to use the data may be obtained by contacting the distributor.
latestVersion.citationRequirements: National Opinion Research Center. STUDY OF OCCUPATIONAL PRESTIGE, USA 1947 [Computer file] Chicago, IL: National Opinion Research Center [distributor].

datasetContactAffiliation.value: University of California, Los Angeles. Social Science Data Archive.

dsDescriptionValue.value: This 1947 NORC study of occupational prestige uses the Alphabetical Index of Occupations and Industries, published  by the US Bureau of the Census, 140 Edition. The study was carried out to measure patterns of occupational status inheritance in the United States. Data were collected on three generations of occupational history for men and women in a nationally representative study. Questions include occupational goals and decisions, work history, occupation, industry, perceptions of occupations, educational goals and history, veteran status, father's work history, occupation and industry, home ownership, presidential preferences and vote in 1944, age, sex and race (white or black).

topicClassValue.value: Occupational, Geographic, and Social Stratification and Mobility

fields.value: Version Date: 1987Version Text: NORC version Subject: STANDARD DEPOSIT TERMS 1.0  Type: DATAPASS:TERMS:STANDARD:1.0  Notes: The UCLA Social Science Data Archive (“the Archive”) gives permission and any required licenses to Data-PASS to make the Content available for archiving, preservation and access (with permission of the Archive), within the Data Preservation Alliance for the Social Sciences ("Data-PASS") in accordance with the Data-PASS terms (the "Terms") of use (available from: http://www.icpsr.org/Data-PASS). Including permission to: (a) redisseminate copies of the Data Collection in a variety of distribution formats only according to the standard terms of use of the Archive; (b) promote and advertise the Data Collection in any publicity (in any form) for Data-PASS and the Archive; (c) describe, catalog, validate and document the Content; (d) store, translate, copy or re-format the Data Collection in any way to ensure its future preservation and accessibility, improve usability and/or protect respondent confidentiality; (e) incorporate metadata (cataloging information) or documentation regarding this study into public access catalogues. The Archive represents and warrants that the Content conforms to all Terms and that the Archive is lawfully entitled and has full authority to license Data-Pass to use the Materials in the ways described in the Terms.;
University of California. Los Angeles. Social Science Data Archive

value: Goyder, John C. and Curtis, James E. Three-generational approach to trends in occupational. mobility. AMERICAN JOURNAL OF SOCIOLOGY, v 81, no 1, July 1975, pp 129-138.

fields.value: This study was originally in a multiple punch format.  NORC researcher Patrick Bova converted the multiple punch file to ASCII.
